ocr.line: ἀριστεύειν περὶ τὴν τοῦ σώματος κομιδήν· καὶ κρι-
ocr.sentence: Πεπτωκότος γὰρ ἐν τῇ μάχῃ τοῦ Ἀχιλλέως ἐδόκουν Αἴας τε καὶ Ὀδυσσεὺς ἐπ’ αὐτῷ πλέον u ἀριστεύειν περὶ τὴν τοῦ σώματος κομιδήν· καὶ κρι- νομένων περὶ τῶν ὅπλων, κρατεῖ Ὀδυσσεὺς, ὅθεν ὁ Αας, τῆς κρίσεως μὴ Tuyav, παρακεκίνηται zul διέ- φθαρται τὴν γνώμην, ὦστε ἐφαπτόμενος τῶν ποιμνίων δοκεῖν τοὺς Ἕλληνας διαχρήσασθαι, καὶ Ta μὲν ἀνεῖλε Tüv τετραπόδων, za δὲ δήσας ἀπάγει ἐπὶ τὴν σκηνὴν, ἐν οἷς ἐστι καὶ κριός τις ἔξοχος, ὃν Wero εἶναι Ὀδυσ- cu, iv δήσας ἐμαστίγωσεν, ὅθεν καὶ τῇ ἐπιγραφῇ πρόςκειται ὁ Μαστιγοφόρος, ἢ πρὸς ἀντιδιαστολὴν τοῦ Λοκροῦ.
ocr.region: To δρᾶμα τῆς τρωϊκῆς ἐστι πραγματείας, ὥςπερ οἱ Ἀντηνορίδαι καὶ Αἰχμαλωτίδες nal Ἑλένης ἁρπαγὴ καὶ Μέμνον. Πεπτωκότος γὰρ ἐν τῇ μάχῃ τοῦ Ἀχιλλέως ἐδόκουν Αἴας τε καὶ Ὀδυσσεὺς ἐπ’ αὐτῷ πλέον u ἀριστεύειν περὶ τὴν τοῦ σώματος κομιδήν· καὶ κρι- νομένων περὶ τῶν ὅπλων, κρατεῖ Ὀδυσσεὺς, ὅθεν ὁ Αας, τῆς κρίσεως μὴ Tuyav, παρακεκίνηται zul διέ- φθαρται τὴν γνώμην, ὦστε ἐφαπτόμενος τῶν ποιμνίων δοκεῖν τοὺς Ἕλληνας διαχρήσασθαι, καὶ Ta μὲν ἀνεῖλε Tüv τετραπόδων, za δὲ δήσας ἀπάγει ἐπὶ τὴν σκηνὴν, ἐν οἷς ἐστι καὶ κριός τις ἔξοχος, ὃν Wero εἶναι Ὀδυσ- cu, iv δήσας ἐμαστίγωσεν, ὅθεν καὶ τῇ ἐπιγραφῇ πρόςκειται ὁ Μαστιγοφόρος, ἢ πρὸς ἀντιδιαστολὴν τοῦ Λοκροῦ. Δκαίαρχος de Αἴαντος θάνατον Enı- άφει· ἐν δὲ ταῖς διδασκαλίαις ψιλῶς Αἴας ava- γγραπται.
groundtruth.line: ἀριστεύειν περὶ τὴν τοῦ σώματος κομιδήν· καὶ κρι-
groundtruth.sentence: Πεπτωκότος γὰρ ἐν τῇ μάχῃ τοῦ Ἀχιλλέως ἐδόκουν Αἴας τε καὶ Ὀδυσσεὺς ἐπ’ αὐτῷ πλέον τι ἀριστεύειν περὶ τὴν τοῦ σώματος κομιδήν· καὶ κρι- νομένων περὶ τῶν ὅπλων, κρατεῖ Ὀδυσσεὺς, ὅθεν ὁ Αἴας, τῆς κρίσεως μὴ τυχὼν, παρακεκίνηται καὶ διέ- φθαρται τὴν γνώμην, ὥστε ἐφαπτόμενος τῶν ποιμνίων δοκεῖν τοὺς Ἕλληνας διαχρήσασθαι, καὶ τὰ μὲν ἀνεῖλε τῶν τετραπόδων, τὰ δὲ δήσας ἀπάγει ἐπὶ τὴν σκηνὴν, ἐν οἷς ἐστι καὶ κριός τις ἔξοχος, ὃν ᾤετο εἶναι Ὀδυσ- σέα, ὃν δήσας ἐμαστίγωσεν, ὅθεν καὶ τῇ ἐπιγραφῇ πρόςκειται ὁ Μαστιγοφόρος, ἢ πρὸς ἀντιδιαστολὴν τοῦ Λοκροῦ.
groundtruth.region: Τὸ δρᾶμα τῆς τρωϊκῆς ἐστι πραγματείας, ὥςπερ οἱ Ἀντηνορίδαι καὶ Αἰχμαλωτίδες καὶ Ἑλένης ἁρπαγὴ καὶ Μέμνων. Πεπτωκότος γὰρ ἐν τῇ μάχῃ τοῦ Ἀχιλλέως ἐδόκουν Αἴας τε καὶ Ὀδυσσεὺς ἐπ’ αὐτῷ πλέον τι ἀριστεύειν περὶ τὴν τοῦ σώματος κομιδήν· καὶ κρι- νομένων περὶ τῶν ὅπλων, κρατεῖ Ὀδυσσεὺς, ὅθεν ὁ Αἴας, τῆς κρίσεως μὴ τυχὼν, παρακεκίνηται καὶ διέ- φθαρται τὴν γνώμην, ὥστε ἐφαπτόμενος τῶν ποιμνίων δοκεῖν τοὺς Ἕλληνας διαχρήσασθαι, καὶ τὰ μὲν ἀνεῖλε τῶν τετραπόδων, τὰ δὲ δήσας ἀπάγει ἐπὶ τὴν σκηνὴν, ἐν οἷς ἐστι καὶ κριός τις ἔξοχος, ὃν ᾤετο εἶναι Ὀδυσ- σέα, ὃν δήσας ἐμαστίγωσεν, ὅθεν καὶ τῇ ἐπιγραφῇ πρόςκειται ὁ Μαστιγοφόρος, ἢ πρὸς ἀντιδιαστολὴν τοῦ Λοκροῦ. Δικαίαρχος δὲ Αἴαντος θάνατον ἐπι- γράφει· ἐν δὲ ταῖς διδασκαλίαις ψιλῶς Αἴας ἀνα- γέγραπται.

Because of its statistical rather than deterministic and high-probability approach to morphological analysis, the ICmorph lexical tools can be easily and effectively used to precisely recognize morphophonemic features like syllabification, vowel gradation, diphthongization and monophthongization, hence suitable and optimal for the orthographic analysis and correction of known inconsistent and inaccurate linguistic models due to non-linguistically trained programmers and linguists in the automatic conversion of documents into a digitized version.

Because of the intrinsic inconsistency of non-orthographic writing systems, it is impossible to reconstruct the original transcription when the orthographic or phonemic transcription is corrupted, hence an unreliable text is produced. Successful proofreading and editing of documents with an uncertain or misspelled transcription, requires a linguistically accurate segmentation of the text into homogenous morpheme structure.

The software is available interfacing only ANSI C programming language, hence programming steps can be easily transferred to other implementation languages, such as Fortran 90, Lahey/GNU C compiler, Unix shell-scripting languages, Tcl, Perl, or Python. Additionally, ICmorph has been ported to several CPU architectures with embedded cross-cpu-toolchains. The programmer, considering memory constrictions of small micro-computers, can easily modify the code to accommodate for CPU instruction bytecode size, employing a simple built-in API. This applies to multi-computer and network/system configurations including multi-core CPU architectures.

Find the semicolon in the following awkward text:
<poem>
So fades a sunlight from the west; 
So sinks the breeze along the forest trees;
Or Rainbow from the stormy cloud; 
Or smile from Dian’s cheek;— 
All’s tintless idly as before: 
When Thou in joy- Sunn’st on the unblest shelt’ring wood, 
Laugh’st with the flow’r that hath no voice, 
To Thee meek Bird! in silence oft aloft 
Floats on your dun-ellips with dim wing.
LEWIS.</poem>

According to Merlin Pharr, “parallelism, even if not very logical, is often pleasing.” So could a revised version read as follows:
<poem>
So fades a sunlight from the west, 
So sinks the breeze along the forest trees,
Or Rainbow from the stormy cloud, 
Or Rainbow from the stormy cloud,
Or smile from Dian’s cheek:—all’s tintless idly as before:
When Thou in joy- Sunn’st on the unblest shelt’ring wood
Laugh’st with the flow’r that hath no voice,
To Thee meek Bird in silence oft aloft!
Floats on thy dun-ellips with dim wing.
LEWIS.</poem>

The poem appears to begin in B flat and close in A minor.

The general effect of versification is prosodically difficult but musically acute.

The poem has two possible points of musical emphasis: after “Sun” and “Of The”.

There are, however, an inexplicable number of words of three letters, as well as an inordinate number of words of four letters.

In the following two lines, count the number of words with more than five letters:

There are only four, and all the longer words are verbs. Something’s wrong.
For example, there are more than 63 words of just four letters in the first 71 lines of Parnell’s "Ode on the Popular Superstitions of the Highlands of Scotland".

Fitness for publication is a complex matter. In rare cases, Harper or Penguin might ask for one letter from the submitted MS to be replaced—as Ernest Hemingway was asked to change an t in "For Whom The Bell Tolls" to an h . prediction.sentence:
ἡμέρα κλίνει κἀνάγει πάλιν ἅπαντα τἀνθρώπεια· τοὺς σώφρονας θεοὶ φιλοῦσι καὶ στυγοῦσι τοὺς κακούς.

This is a classical example of the lowercase letters in a static environment, which are always sized as capitals. Such in fact is the behavior of many common word processors. So, to help keep text that needs processing, move small instances of this kind of lettering into their own alphabetical pool.

INSIGNIA

The main category is emblem, a marker of membership in a group or organization. The decoration of emblems, described by using a separate editing category, Project to enhance the metadata. The text of the emblem is edited as consistently as possible with the rest of its pool, whether the pool for the editing category is a manuscript to which the emblem belongs, or a book that includes it.

See also Edit section about the use of square brackets to separate emblems from the text, substituting a few null characters or meaningless characters, which are always visible, to differentiate them from punctuation marks that may overlap in the text.

A second category for large text blocks is blob, a large spherical or irregularly-shaped ornament. This might represent the insignia of a group or an unusual decoration, a heraldic device, or music notation. Blobs do not have a consistent length, which makes them unsuitable for re-used editing categories.

In a third category belong multi-chapter items. This category can contain several editable items—in practice, one item is often a prose item, and a second item is often an emblem. The edit hierarchy for multi-chapter items is unclear. Consider jettisoning them and recreating them, reducing them number.

Emblem Edit the complete article, which contains the intro, history, content, variations and bibliography of the emblem and the accompanying emblem image. Edit the infobox, which includes the article in a pre-populated data structure. The members of the related emblemato cluster are examples for the motto, the variants, the translations, and interpretations. Not all project participants are interested in editing the emblem, but the project prohibits this. For coordination reasons, remove the emblem article from the trunk of the archetype.

Here is an example of an emblem content page from an encyclopedia, and an example of the Infobox.

Blob Edit every blob, regardless of how large, as elaborated much as possible. Some amount of mis-registration can occasionally be useful for permitting the blob to fit constrained image space. See Project to enhance the metadata. The sorting order for text is usually sequence, but for blobs it is poetry, matching the form of a rosette or chain of small blobs. In general, images other than calligraphy are usually accompanied by text. Editing the text if there is no calligraphy will create a canon in calligraphy. If there is calligraphy, consider using mathematical formulas to explain the mark, based upon the imaginary content.

Multi-chapter Edit as many of these, especially in books, as you can. These include toys and skulls found in books, incipits and colophons in books, and front and back covers of books.

NOTE: The following section does not contain all the edit categories that are used for this process. Instead, this section provides examples and explanations of some of the more commonly used categories that are not included in the above topic, and they may be suitable for editing other material. Consider expanding this section.

Canon source Edit is usually limited to a single source (unless there are problems with the source, differences in version, or a controversy among scholars) and constitutes an entire narrative or a significant part of it. The source is stored in a source area, separated from the text of the item. Therefore, this category usually has few instances.

Primary Source Edit provides the source for paragraphs that are always edited as from the original source, in edited form and in translation. The template(s) Edit the template This link will take you to a wiki page providing templates for the projects and editing categories that are used within this project. See also This link will take you to a wiki page providing templates for the projects and editing categories that are used within this project.

Primary source Edit editors, Not all editions of texts use italics to indicate sections of primary source text. Discourage this, requiring editors to either follow or produce something that blends with the page, perhaps using a boxed format. The

In addition, the proposed emendation makes very good sense of the linving assonance pattern in the emended text, which is more typically Achaian, and the word for ‘swine’.“Bent in swinish sound” is much better than “heard of some troubles respecting taxes and other public matters”.“breams here and there, with which the darkness vanishes more quickly” is a typically Achaian manner of describing a light or epiphany.Given the clear gerundive active 1 in ‘’ ismeneus agapa’’ (line 345, ‘looking kindly at us’) I think ‘’hνγος’ is to be taken as a related form. In his hexameter Muse: Edouard Will inferred ‘κλάων’ with a very similar description of the lightning’s flight path, and I think ‘’ is also preferred rather than ‘’ here – perhaps ‘the fierceness of sunlight’.note: Gene M. Look has made the following comment on my proposed emendation in a recent posting on academia.edu:There is no 2nd person accusative θέρων after the verb νυκτὸς αἰανῆς, which would mean that τεῇ φέγγος αἰανῇς should be taken as accusative. φέγγος αἰανῇς has an obscure Hesychian form which could be τεύεα. Using optical character recognition (OCR) applications, can convert handwritten or typewritten text into digital files to allow further manipulation. New approaches can also fully automate OCR processes, which will allow fully automated translation functions. However, not every OCR engine is able to correctly recognize text. It is a multidisciplinary task with language engineering, computer vision & pattern recognition, artificial intelligence, statistics, mathematics, signal processing, econometrics, CS, and more.

A problem in the use of optical character recognition (OCR) software for the digitization of historical documents, such as letters, manuscripts, or other handwritten sources is character errors and writing features caused by the structure of the paper and pen use. Limits in optical character recognition accuracy and formatting of digital source files make the correction of optically scanned texts difficult and time consuming.

Click on (?) if you don't know the word. Hover over to compare your reading to other transcriptions. Leave your answer in comments. Challenge yourself, your friends or family. This is not just a set of exercises in reading; it is about feeling poetry, rhetoric and imaginative text. Is it subjective? Of course. Correct in brackets with audio.
Over years (over two decades of technological madness) the TIGIT approach was proven across various languages and domains (linguistics, literature, law, chemistry, material sciences). The most valid approach to correctness, as far as a piece of a text is concerned, falls under two categories: contextual and syntactic. Contextual correctness is affected by stability, synergy (Greek: συνέρεεσθαι) of expression with the macrostructure, repetition and consistency of its placement in the text. On the other hand, syntactic correctness involves stability, synergy, close relationship with other expressions but primarily one's ability to withstand time, maintain contextual correctness along with other factors. Shorter expressions, especially if they make up more than half of the text are even more likely to prove their textual value on the spot (γλῶσσα λιγεσίᾳ καύσται is a cool poetic line indeed - it is from the Odyssey). It is at that point where TIGIT entails numerous phonetic and probabilistic procedures such as frequency, morphological similarity, historical context, morphology and syntax. Success is carefully built upon these assumptions but when the textual situation is wrought with mistakes, in depth decision rules are modulated on text pairs which determine the correspondence between strict rules and exceptional sentences.

The Internet Archive has a research effort named “News Optical Character Recognition (OCR) Pilot”. The research effort is focused on migrating historical newspapers available on the Internet Archive into a format that is more stable and usable. Their efforts can be utilized by project idea/thesis authors.

There are many efforts to manufacture computer algorithms that can read scanned materials. Some of these efforts are listed below: 

Project Gutenberg provides free, out-of-copyright, books. Its non-English-language-books project currently has translations for 20 languages. Project Gutenberg can be found here:
Most books listed at this site are in PDF or plain text format and not in locked formats. This allows readers to attempt to convert them into a more OCR-friendly format.
prediction.sentence:
τοῖγ’ άρ’ εἶναι μέλλομεν θεοῖς εἴκειν· μαθησόμεσθα δέ Ἀτρείδας σέβειν.
The corrected Greek text is:

ὡς μὲν μέλλομεν εἶναι θεοῖς εἴκειν, μαθησόμεσθα δέ Ἀτρείδας σέβειν.
The Latin text is:

itaque nos, qui essemus in ultimo loco, fibi goderemus immittendos in Cretae, Platonem eamus, qui videndus est, quiudeamos.

The passage originates from the "In pace", a treatise that, stylistically, has not lost all traces of limping oratory that characterized Roman monumental prose of the first century BCE. The author extends this "oratorical" style of writing to the very content, his goal is precisely that of rendering the thought in speech itself. It is therefore no surprise that he himself uses at different points in the text the expressions "voco igitur", "et audi, una ex illo tempore", "necque aegre ea existimo", "ostendens tum" (literally breaking off from what he was saying and turning with arms around the listener), "nunc" (immediately) and (if we consider the entire speech) "vocem histrio oportet" (the need not to save verbal energy, which is the function of actors), for "number et tono notandos" emphasizes not "vocibus autem ratione utendum est", but rather "ritu quidem dicendi numerique tragoedi... mollitiim est necessitate et tonitru gravi de competere. The lack of syntax reflects the goal of strengthening the representation of spoken language. For this reason, it also happened that certain words of the original text (i.e., in this case the exordium of Seneca in Ad Marciam) were decided to complete the ancient text with modern equivalents: in fact, during the speech, Seneca used purely rhetorical techniques of his literary culture, (and in particular the pyrrhic form), whereas the original text is written in hexameters. These are not errors of importance only or purely philological trivialities, but they testify to the sort of exaggeration that characterizes the language of the work in question, perfectly matching the most pronounced features of imperial scholarship and providing a key stylistical characteristic to the rest of the text, whose diction is almost entirely mimetical. The style of the maxim in Seneca is a “ghostly tissue”, with discrepancies in the transport of sentences containing poetic contrasts that actually symbolize the key structures of a rhetorical text. The Ritschlian critical edition of Seneca, which is an academic project sponsored by the Austrian Academy of Sciences, has only published the Greek text of the "Apocolocyntosis divi Claudii", imposing on everyone the interpretation (which I have already partly reported) according to which it must be considered as a mistake on the part of a copyist, understandable when considering the difficulty of Seneca's Greek (since it had been interspersed by four Latin maxims), easy to consider as pedantic or rhetorical, by contrast to Latin that was simpler and more direct. Even if the term ""errare humanum est"" does not apply to the sources inscribed in books, human culture illustrates poets, rhetoricians and philosophers of the continuous effort to find a model only to be replaced by an equal and contrary law productive of discords, discordances and conflicts. Philip Burton (1994) in a profound study of history, tradition structure of the literature of the Western world sees a constant in the meaning of civilization: a meter litotica centripetal, which flows out of a single hub and trend. The "Apocolocyntosis perernative", introduces readers to an alternative that changes the stylistic position of the fiction by adopting, on the one hand, all the "pace" of narrated banalities of a European Roman, on the other hand the expressive and semantic content of an ancient writer always characterized by lyrical tonalities.

An accurate study of the above observations are reported in the poem "Iambics on Rome. The price of faith," where the expression of a continuous development employed by Philip Burton, to end the poetic work with a scene that

In addition, the proposed emendation makes very good sense of the linving assonance pattern in the emended text, which is more typically Achaian, and the word for ‘swine’.“Bent in swinish sound” is much better than “heard of some troubles respecting taxes and other public matters”.“breams here and there, with which the darkness vanishes more quickly” is a typically Achaian manner of describing a light or epiphany.Given the clear gerundive active 1 in ‘’ ismeneus agapa’’ (line 345, ‘looking kindly at us’) I think ‘’hνγος’ is to be taken as a related form. In his hexameter Muse: Edouard Will inferred ‘κλάων’ with a very similar description of the lightning’s flight path, and I think ‘’ is also preferred rather than ‘’ here – perhaps ‘the fierceness of sunlight’.note: Gene M. Look has made the following comment on my proposed emendation in a recent posting on academia.edu:There is no 2nd person accusative θέρων after the verb νυκτὸς αἰανῆς, which would mean that τεῇ φέγγος αἰανῇς should be taken as accusative. φέγγος αἰανῇς has an obscure Hesychian form which could be τεύεα. There are well attested examples sentence and verse ending with ἄεῇ in 4th c. Attic verb forms. Elsewhere, this word is found as an administrative preposition ‘ἐς’. There is a hexameter line from his own ‘’ (IE 18.212, ed. Ts. Cartledge p. 266): ἐς τοσόνδ’ ἐχθαρτέος ‘’Giving to him little, he will give back to you’’. So, there is an attested instance of the discourse-penult εἰς τόσους in the 4th c.

ἄμβροτ’ ἔρπει βιαζόμενος

The Bayeux Tapestry is a late 11th- / early 12th-century embroidered cloth nearly long decorating the events leading up to the Norman conquest of England. Most of the embroidery is devoted to the narration of a single event: the career of Harold Godwinson, culminating in a scene of his death and the victory of the Duke of Normandy. The Tapestry represents a magnificent showcase of the finest possible work of its time, both in gold thread and with the creation of new forms of expression.

The contents of the Bayeux Tapestry depict the events that unfolded following William the Conqueror’s victory over Harold Godwinson in the battle of Hastings on 14 October 1066. According to some of the accounts, the Battle of Hastings lasted two days with an interval to bury the dead before Duke William was able to continue the fighting. The Tapestry shows no such break, nor any scene of Harold formally surrendering or seeking reconciliation. So it has been suggested that the Norman victors embarked on a massive plundering the night after the battle and the following mid-morning on 15 October Harold was struck down by the Norman horsemen and killed.

The blank space appears in the Tapestry about the time the fighting ends. For some decades both sides kept very quiet about the result of the Battle of Hastings. It was almost certainly embroidered before the event. The first mention of the Tapestry appears about 1210.

Population of England grew rapidly in the years before 1066: England supported 60,000 soldiers in 1069,

Correct the spelling and grammar of the following incorrect text from a handwritten source:

Incorrect text: Τῶν μὲν Ti κωμῶν Ti we κωμῶν


Christopher Robert Brown Best


Cleonian Prose Style


As a soldier on campaign, his behavior would not have been a point of comment. He invariably yielded the command to another officer, a distinction mentioned in one of eleven extant letters.1 Plutarch (Aristides 21.4) and Philostratus (Ep. Herc. 446) describe his practice of degrading men to menial status for moral failures. In an assembly of citizens, he could have been rhetorically gagged by his opponent in the kratasia (Schol. Lyc. 56). In none of these situations has any particular sophistication in the technologies of persuasion surfaced. Of course, there are few constraints on the use of rhetoric in a soldierly capacity, not even when one is telling stories to a marching army (7.329c). The fact that Longinus has a chapter on him in the first place indicates that in the early phases of the Roman Empire it did not offer many options involving exalted discourse.

The effect on the soldier’s oratorical persona was profound. He was the subject of three panegyrics, the only extant examples of this form of literary genre from antiquity (Habicht, 1982: 234–52). Like his predecessor Eumenes II of Pergamum (Polybius 18.11.4–21), Antony attended a school, where the old age him to linger while he was still learning the basics of reading (Plutarch, Ant. 8.1). Beyond these handfuls of parallels it is impossible to state what he learned in the school without access to the teacher’s story of his student. In any case, taking twenty teachers as the average number of residents of one and a half acres, the number attending its lectures, we have to admit that only a small part would have benefited from a good teacher (Frier, 1975b). That is, learning happened exceedingly slowly and inefficiently, in a society over a tenth of which had no formal schooling (Frier, 1975a). Moreover, the citizens who in Plutarch (Qu.Graec. 335CD) is the author of the synteresis discussed above gave rise to that rule are representative of the circumstances of the most part of the citizen body. Only the wealthy and the few chosen for special training were the subjects of well-written speeches. The common people withdrew from politics, having been excluded from political rights, their deafness a symptom of the indifference they felt for the bulk of issues of government.2

Against these imperfections of either education and of rhetoric, men like any other, three aspects distinguish them above their fellows.3 First, they were students for life, not like the rustic and plebeian speakers who learned by immersion in the abstractions of speeches which… have neither memories nor written works to sustain them (Plutarch, Alex. 46.6). They benefited from biographies, tragedies, and the critical attitude exposed by Socrates and Plato in the Republic and the Gorgias, all traditions carried on by the school that taught rhetoric.4 Second, they supported the development of poetry and literature. Future betterment of state and society relied on their building reading habits among broad segments of the population, while rhetoric was the art by which we express our views clearly and persuasively (2.13.1). How could one ensure that such vital abilities guaranteed the success of a state? The answer, while improving political

Theodorus, Eusebius and Pamphilus-all born in Caesarea-found a document in the pontificate of Eusebius which Origen had sent to bishops all over the world for safekeeping.

The corrected text collects two factual aberrations, both requiring factual corrections:

1. Date of document (Origen’s and Fabian’s pontificate), 2. addition of 2nd name (Eusebius). (displacing Theodorus who already got corrected from Theodorus to Theodorus and Eusebius. The correction of the 2nd name (Eusebius) is now unnecessary.)

Correct the spelling and grammar of the following incorrect text from a handwritten source:

Incorrect text: Τῶν μὲν Ti κωμῶν Ti we κωμῶν


Christopher Robert Brown Best


Cleonian Prose Style


As a soldier on campaign, his behavior would not have been a point of comment. He invariably yielded the command to another officer, a distinction mentioned in one of eleven extant letters.1 Plutarch (Aristides 21.4) and Philostratus (Ep. Herc. 446) describe his practice of degrading men to menial status for moral failures. In an assembly of citizens, he could have been rhetorically gagged by his opponent in the kratasia (Schol. Lyc. 56). In none of these situations has any particular sophistication in the technologies of persuasion surfaced. Of course, there are few constraints on the use of rhetoric in a soldierly capacity, not even when one is telling stories to a marching army (7.329c). The fact that Longinus has a chapter on him in the first place indicates that in the early phases of the Roman Empire it did not offer many options involving exalted discourse.

The effect on the soldier’s oratorical persona was profound. He was the subject of three panegyrics, the only extant examples of this form of literary genre from antiquity (Habicht, 1982: 234–52). Like his predecessor Eumenes II of Pergamum (Polybius 18.11.4–21), Antony attended a school, where the old age him to linger while he was still learning the basics of reading (Plutarch, Ant. 8.1). Beyond these handfuls of parallels it is impossible to state what he learned in the school without access to the teacher’s story of his student. In any case, taking twenty teachers as the average number of residents of one and a half acres, the number attending its lectures, we have to admit that only a small part would have benefited from a good teacher (Frier, 1975b). That is, learning happened exceedingly slowly and inefficiently, in a society over a tenth of which had no formal schooling (Frier, 1975a). Moreover, the citizens who in Plutarch (Qu.Graec. 335CD) is the author of the synteresis discussed above gave rise to that rule are representative of the circumstances of the most part of the citizen body. Only the wealthy and the few chosen for special training were the subjects of well-written speeches. The common people withdrew from politics, having been excluded from political rights, their deafness a symptom of the indifference they felt for the bulk of issues of government.2

Against these imperfections of either education and of rhetoric, men like any other, three aspects distinguish them above their fellows.3 First, they were students for life, not like the rustic and plebeian speakers who learned by immersion in the abstractions of speeches which… have neither memories nor written works to sustain them (Plutarch, Alex. 46.6). They benefited from biographies, tragedies, and the critical attitude exposed by Socrates and Plato in the Republic and the Gorgias, all traditions carried on by the school that taught rhetoric.4 Second, they supported the development of poetry and literature. Future betterment of state and society relied on their building reading habits among broad segments of the population, while rhetoric was the art by which we express our views clearly and persuasively (2.13.1). How could one ensure that such vital abilities guaranteed the success of a state? The answer, while improving political

The application of intelligent d-r sequence detection in OCR attempts to distinguish and recover the (mis)printed word in source text, when the letter "d" and the vowel diagraph (containing d) are adjacent to each other in a word.,

Look has made the following comment on my proposed emendation in a recent posting on academia.edu:There is no 2nd person accusative θέρων after the verb νυκτὸς αἰανῆς, which would mean that τεῇ φέγγος αἰανῇς should be taken as accusative. φέγγος αἰανῇς has an obscure Hesychian form which could be τεύεα. There are well attested examples sentence and verse ending with ἄεῇ in 4th c. Attic verb forms. Elsewhere, this word is found as an administrative preposition ‘ἐς’. There is a hexameter line from his own ‘’ (IE 18.212, ed. Ts. Cartledge p. 266): ἐς τοσόνδ’ ἐχθαρτέος ‘’Giving to him little, he will give back to you’’. So, there is an attested instance of the discourse-penult εἰς τόσους in the 4th c.

In addition, the proposed emendation makes very good sense of the linving assonance pattern in the emended text, which is more typically Achaian, and the word for ‘swine’.“Bent in swinish sound” is much better than “heard of some troubles respecting taxes and other public matters”.“breams here and there, with which the darkness vanishes more quickly” is a typically Achaian manner of describing a light or epiphany.Given the clear gerundive active 1 in ‘’ ismeneus agapa’’ (line 345, ‘looking kindly at us’) I think ‘’hνγος’ is to be taken as a related form. In his hexameter Muse: Edouard Will inferred ‘κλάων’ with a very similar description of the lightning’s flight path, and I think ‘’ is also preferred rather than ‘’ here – perhaps ‘the fierceness of sunlight’.note: Gene M. Look has made the following comment on my proposed emendation in a recent posting on academia.edu:There is no 2nd person accusative θέρων after the verb νυκτὸς αἰανῆς, which would mean that τεῇ φέγγος αἰανῇς should be taken as accusative. φέγγος αἰανῇς has an obscure Hesychian form which could be τεύεα. There are well attested examples sentence and verse ending with ἄεῇ in 4th c. Attic verb forms. Elsewhere, this word is found as an administrative preposition ‘ἐς’. There is a hexameter line from his own ‘’ (IE 18.212, ed. Ts. Cartledge p. 266): ἐς τοσόνδ’ ἐχθαρτέος ‘’Giving to him little, he will give back to you’’. So, there is an attested instance of the discourse-penult εἰς τόσους in the 4th c.

The Unified Greek New Testament (Grabis et al., 2006) "expurgated text with morphological tagging" remains the standard critical edition. The text is also available at the non-profit Bibleworks.

The Greek New Testament (Origen and Eusebius from Version V of the Nestle-Aland editions, Lagrange, Thayer; all text-types except the Majority text, which is Christologic and lacks the spurious "Pericope Adulterae"; Wright, 2003), is the most recent critical edition. The text is available at The Perseus Project.

Look has made the following comment on my proposed emendation in a recent posting on academia.edu:There is no 2nd person accusative θέρων after the verb νυκτὸς αἰανῆς, which would mean that τεῇ φέγγος αἰανῇς should be taken as accusative. φέγγος αἰανῇς has an obscure Hesychian form which could be τεύεα. There are well attested examples sentence and verse ending with ἄεῇ in 4th c. Attic verb forms. Elsewhere, this word is found as an administrative preposition ‘ἐς’. So, there is an attested instance of the discourse-penult εἰς τόσους in the 4th c.

The palaeographical analysis of cuneiform tablets is a challenging task, in fact the more you see them, the more difficult they become to interpret. Many are published, for example, Keilschrifttexte der Hethiter, but they all have the same problem. Pure cuneiform texts are rare, as Hetzron noted in his Ancient Aramaic and Hebrew Letters. He also compared them to the palaeographical interpretation of Early Medieval Anglo-Saxon runic amulets. The reasons for this comment become apparent as one works through various letter combinations. It may not be possible given the current understanding of cuneiform script to interpret all tablet texts using conventional philological techniques. Once a few of the letter groups have been correctly identified, it is clear that there are several methods of interpreting them semantically, which may account for the mutilated nature of some tablets. Further methodology may need to involve some form of cryptographic algorithm to undertake analysis of texts such as this:

However, once experienced, the letters can begin to slot together very quickly. It is not unusual to be able to resolve the contents of a cuneiform tablet, consisting of up to fifteen lines, within a few minutes. Indeed, the versatility of cuneiform with the sub-literaries, phonograms and ligatures enables a word analysis of most words and phrases once they have been correctly identified. A high degree of precision can be obtained by analysing the word or even syllable by syllable, letter by letter. In fact, some tablets employ the fox hieroglyph in the first position of a phrase to indicate an oblique case ending added to the initial word (see for example Warrnambool II). In short, this method is considered to be the most philologically precise, and is used in the production of the Cuneiform Digital Library Initiative and DLIB.

Recent philological work has had some success in mapping the phonetic signs appearing in the syllabification lists used as pronunciations of lexical forms in titles of governance officials (Enlil.69 to Enl
prediction.sentence:
σωτηρίαν εἶναι τούτον ἐπίστασο.

The Greek alphabet has eight vowels, each represented by a different letter. The names of the letters are identical to their pronunciation. Greek distinguishes three types of stops: voiceless, voiced and breathy voiced; and four types of liquid consonants: voiced, voiceless, breathy voiced and breathy-voiceless. The remaining consonants are semivowels. The 24 letters are:

The Greek alphabet has eight vowels, each represented by a different letter. The names of the letters are identical to their pronunciation. Greek distinguishes three types of stops: voiceless, voiced and breathy voiced; and four types of liquid consonants: voiced, voiceless, breathy voiced and breathy-voiceless. P. Oxy. 3772, papyrus The city of Miletus was a colony of Lydia that was conquered by the Persians in the early 5 th cent. BCE. Both Herodotus and Aeschylus were Karian* by birth. Herodotus (Herodotus 7.151) mentions the foundation of Lydia and the reason of its foundation, the story behind its foundation is that goes back to mythological ages in the Asia Minor. Miletus, Karystos Bay ( at the southern tip of Loddos peninsula near modern Turkish town of Karystos) and the closest Greek colonies (Phelleo and Gryneion) are listed cities who recognize the convention of the Federation (ΦΙΛΙΣ) which was founded by Tydeus, Adaön, Klymenos, and Thales of Miletus (Plataians T11:2-7). The word is spelled (sic!) also in Linear B tablets which date back to 15 th cent. BCE in the Mycenaean and un-Mycenaean periods (Palamaea GI). Relation to Pelops-Kuturnos adventures in the Phokis region… * Lack of detailed information on Karystos and Kerystos of Rhodes was caused to the heavy bombardment during the ‘s is one of the oldest known literary units known, Diktynna. Most probably this is the nymph of Karystos of Rhodes but there are two words: karydna and karytheron which identify Zeus’s Nymphs whom according to Dionysos of Carystos would have brought Artemis from the Mt. Nisaas the mountain near a lake region of Palairosa near modern Turkish town of Mersin. The city of Tyre (‘our lady …’) of today Lebanon is most probably related with Diktynna perhaps for the mythical/religious marriage between King Tyre/Leto Zeus’s daughter and Phoenicians (St. Cyriac’s Tabulae p. 105) due to the major naval tradition of both Tyre and Phoenicia. Around 350 BCE, the Phoenician settlers on Tenos while discussing the issues on colonization an appropriate place for the new colony, suggest to found it on uninhabitated Tenos, between Phoenician colonies and on the land that belonged to them (Eus. PE 14:15).

Create a technical design for a museum exhibit about the Magna Carta based on collected materials and existing exhibit design layouts. Place yourself among the barons at Runnymede. What important lessons are learned from King John’s War and King John’s repeated actions? In which ways are rulers and subjects tied together by the idea of allegiance and in what ways are they separate? Are there other documents that need to be drafted to accurately express the barons’ concerns? Create the text and images for the Movable Type installation of the Magna Carta based on the following text document: Instructions to Textile Workers, from Hugh Tucker in 1656:

Incorrect text: Take of brued flax two part, or if it be for making cheane or gause take three parts of brued flax, and of raw flax an othr one and a half part; if to make tape on purpose trevle two or three part: if to make the double seale of this marrow half and half or by equal porcons: if to make fine cheane, taffatum, stampt piece and such like, then fine flax, marow and worsted in equal parts, or if earthen ware as chess or backets, then one and two parts wheerof the worsted and shell.
Now in ordering: if you take more than foure parts of flax the from is double soft and spongy and therefore not for all uses; if you take lesse then foure part, the worke will wither and rot and also in knitting purposes.

PART 1 

Tapestry weevils were a key challenge to creating woven objects of high quality. The weevil caused holes and eats the color in the wool fibers, and cost the 17th-century manufacturer a good part of its profits. Pepper or vinegar was thrown over the wool and garlic rubbed in to give humans some protection from the weevils (Hopkins 2010). What materials were used for textile production in the 17th century? How were these materials transformed into textiles? Namely: how were the individual threads constituted and arranged?

PART 2

A semicolon is a statement separator connecting two related sentences. Do not confuse it with a completion mark, an expectantly awaiting pronoun or an interposed clause, or incorrectly set apart letter pairs in a foreign language words which in silence glided away or to incorrect split Hebrew Bible texts (dikdukei sofrim). Special attention should be given to the occurrence of a semicolon along with a comma, for it appears to be widespread and notably achieved by shoddy OCR. Forget about the comma and correct the second semicolon as manifest by replacing the indefinite pronoun δικαίῳ with the definite article δικαίου.
